awd_titl_txt: NRI: Towards Dexterous Micromanipulation and Assembly
awd_abstract_narration:
Robots that people are familiar with are large, roughly, human-sized.  The theory and design tools for developing such macro-scale robots is well developed.  By contrast, the theory and design tools applicable to tiny, or micro-scale, robots is nearly non-existent.  The goal of this project is to enable the transition of robot manipulation technology from macro-scale robots to micro-scale robots.  The expected project outcomes are: i.) controlled and predictable environments for micro-robotic manipulation and assembly; ii.) a new class of 3D vision-based micro-force sensors and a 3D multi-resolution vision system; and iii.) the identification of dexterous micro-manipulation primitives via human micro-teleoperation with new novel haptic probes.  These results will enable the assembly of micro-scale systems that are currently not possible.  Such systems are applicable across a wide range of domains, such as cm-to-mm scale robots, micro-sensors, steerable catheters, micro-fluidic, and energy harvesting devices.  

At the micro-scale, surface forces dominate the interactions causing unpredictable forces.  This project aims to lay the foundations for tools, such as simulators, motion planners, controllers, etc., to be developed for this unique micro-scale environment.  The research approach is to reduce the uncertainty in forces present in the micro-world to enable dexterous micro-manipulation and assembly.  A new class of manipulation substrates, fixtures, micro-parts, and manipulation tools to control and overcome the levels of adhesion forces present in the micro-world will be created.  To enable force control, 3D vision-based micro-force sensing probes along with a multi-resolution 3D vision system to detect the micro-forces in real-time will be developed.  Dexterous micro-manipulation primitives will be identified from a human tele-operating a multi-probe micro-manipulation system with micro-force feedback in an augmented reality system.  How much and what types of micro-force feedback information is needed for the human to perform different tasks will be studied.  These motion primitives together with physics-based simulators can reduce uncertainty in motion planners.  The insights gained here will dictate the force-control algorithms implemented in future automated systems.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this research was to reduce the uncertainty in forces and perception present in the micro-world to enable dexterous micromanipulation and assembly. The objectives of this proposal were the following: 

  • Objective 1. Controlling Micro-Scale Interaction Forces: The physical characteristics of the manipulation substrate, tools, and micro-parts will be altered to allow for predictable micromanipulation.
  • Objective 2. 3D Vision-Based Micro-Force Sensing & Sub-Diffraction Limit Tracking: A new class of manipulation probes will be realized and used as 3D vision-based micro-force sensors. A multi-resolution 3D vision-system will be created to provide sub-diffraction limit tracking in the workspace for the sensing to a micro-teleoperation and augmented reality system.
  • Objective 3. Micro-Teleoperation and Manipulation Data Tracking: Haptic tools will be used and/or developed that can accurately relay micro-scale manipulation forces to a human operator in a virtual reality system conducting teleoperative micromanipulation tasks. The manipulation data will be tracked in order to extract micromanipulation motion primitives for analysis and eventual remote and/or automated operations. 

 

Intellectual Merit Outcomes:

This research has yielded controlled and predictable environments for micromanipulation and microassembly, a new class of 3D vision-based micro-force sensors along with the requisite multi- and high-resolution 3D vision system, as well as a haptic system and that can accurately relay micro-forces to a human operator in virtual reality that allows for dexterous tele-micromanipulation to be performed and tracked for implementation into future automated systems. All of these contributions will enable the assembly of micro-scale systems from micro-scale components that cannot be manufactured by conventional MEMS manufacturing processes and develop tools and a prototyping ecosystem for new ideas and innovation for small-scale devices.

 

Broader Impacts Outcomes:

The developed system will be used to examine fundamental relationships between surfaces forces and objects at small-scales and to investigate material properties at the micro-scale. The presence or addition of redundant micromanipulators in the test-bed will allow for future extensions where some can have specialized end-effectors for carrying out specific micro-scale manufacturing tasks.

The 3D multi and high-resolution sensing system also has applications in quality control in manufacturing and diagnosis in medicine. Additionally, through the human interaction with the micro-parts via teleoperation, insights into dexterous micromanipulation motion primitives and micro-part features for easier microassembly will become apparent and a new paradigm of design for microassembly could result. Extending the humans reach into the micro-world will generate affordances for people to envision and create what is possible in the realm of integrated micro-systems just like the 3D printer has done for macro-scale system prototyping. The new ways of making will trigger design principles and design needs will change the ways of making. They feed on each other and are iterative. Lessons learned will translate into the design architectures of the fully automated production level advanced micro-manufacturing factories of the future.

This project has impacted the educational experiences of all the 9 undergraduate students, 19 graduate students, and 2 post-doctoral researchers who have been involved with it through the life of the award. All have been exposed to and trained on state-of-the-art technology.  This project has resulted in 33 peer reviewed journal and conference papers and 2 MS theses published.  Additionally, 2 patent applications have been filed based on this research in efforts to translate the developed technology for commercial applications

 


Last Modified: 12/21/2021
Modified by: David Cappelleri
